questions.text: Following administration of a muscle relaxant, the patient develops erythema, flushing and a drop in blood pressure. Which of the following agents is most likely responsible?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given features of erythema, flushing and drop in blood pressure developing after administration of a muscle relaxant point to the use of atracurium.

  • Atracurium is a non-depolarising muscle relaxant with intermediate duration.
  • It undergoes metabolism through plasma esterases and spontaneous degradation in plasma and tissues via Hofmann elimination, producing less-active metabolites.
  • Due to this, it does not show prolonged elimination half-life in patients with renal impairment, making it a suitable choice in such cases.
  • Atracurium can trigger histamine release, potentially causing bronchospasm, hypotension, and increased bronchial and salivary secretions, though the effect is less pronounced than with tubocurarine unless injected rapidly.
  • Cisatracurium, the cis-isomer, is metabolised similarly but is more potent than atracurium and does not cause histamine release. (Option C ruled out)
  • Neuromuscular blocking agents are broadly categorised into depolarising and competitive (non-depolarising) types.
  • Currently, succinylcholine is the only depolarising agent widely used in clinical practice, while several competitive/nondepolarizing agents are available.
  • Their primary applications include aiding endotracheal intubation and providing skeletal muscle relaxation during surgical procedures.
  • Some of the nondepolarizing agents classified according to their duration of action are given in the table below.

Explanation of other options:

Vecuronium (Option A): Vecuronium, a non-depolarising muscle relaxant of intermediate duration, is not commonly associated with histamine release. It undergoes hepatic and renal elimination.

Pancuronium (Option D): Pancuronium, an amino-ester, is a long-acting competitive muscle relaxant that is not frequently associated with histamine release. It exhibits antimuscarinic receptor activity, is eliminated via both the kidneys and liver, and its vagolytic effects can lead to tachycardia, hypertension, and increased cardiac output.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male undergoing abdominal surgery under general anaesthesia developssudden generalised muscle rigidity, rapid increase in body temperature, and tachycardia shortly after administration of sevoflurane and succinylcholine. His end-tidal CO2 is rising despite controlled ventilation. What is the most appropriate immediate treatment?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given clinical features of muscle rigidity, increasing body temperature, and tachycardia after administration of succinylcholine and sevoflurane (inhalational anaesthetic agent) is suggestive of malignant hyperthermia, for which the immediate treatment consists of administration of dantrolene.

The features of malignant hyperthermia are summarised in the table given below.

Explanation of other options:

Paracetamol (Option B): Fever can be managed by giving iced fluids, cooling the skin surface, cooling internal body cavities with sterile fluids, and, if needed, using a heat exchanger connected to a pump oxygenator. Paracetamol is not commonly used.

Propranolol (Option D): Not commonly used in the management of malignant hyperthermia.
